prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not wanting a part in my child's life?
7 years ago I impregnated my girlfriend at the time. I have never wanted children in my life so I offered to pay for an abortion. She wanted to have the child. We stayed together for about 4 months after that and then we broke up. I offered to pay for child support and we got something settled through the courts. Never missed a payment since then.

Since then I have had no contact with our daughter and have not been interested in it. The closest I have to a relationship with her is sending her a gift for her birthday through her mother with instructions that it's from her and not someone else. About 3 days ago I got a call from my ex that she would like the to meet our daughter. I told her I'm not interested and to please not contact me about that again.

Frankly I don't know if the kid is the one that put my ex to it by asking about me or if my ex is the one trying to arrange it.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the author had a child with his ex-girlfriend seven years ago. He didn't want kids and offered to pay for an abortion, but she wanted to keep the child. They stayed together for four months and then broke up. He's been paying child support consistently through court, but hasn't had any contact with his daughter. Now the ex wants him to meet the daughter, but he's refusing and doesn't want any contact.

First, I need to consider the legal aspect. The author is paying child support, which he hasn't missed, so legally he's fulfilling his obligation. But in many places, fathers have the right to parental rights and responsibilities. However, if he was the one who didn't want the child and the mother wanted to proceed, maybe he waived some rights? Or maybe he still has a legal right to be involved. If he's not been involved at all, maybe there's a legal way to terminate his parental rights, but I'm not sure. That might depend on the jurisdiction.

Ethically, though, it's more about the child's well-being. The child has a right to know their father, especially if it's safe and in their best interest. The author is completely cutting himself off, not even engaging in any way beyond financial support. That seems harsh. Even if he didn't want children, once the child was born, having some level of relationship might be beneficial. The fact that the ex is trying to facilitate a meeting now suggests that maybe the child is interested in having a relationship with the father, which the author is refusing.

But the author might have his reasons. Maybe he's not emotionally prepared, or he's worried about being a good parent. But by not even being there, he's denying the child a parent. The question is, is he in the wrong for not wanting to be part of the child's life? Legally, maybe not if he's meeting financial obligations. But morally, yes, because the child has a right to a relationship with both parents if it's feasible and healthy.

Also, the author only sends a gift anonymously. That's a minimal effort. The ex is reaching out now, possibly because the child is curious. The author's refusal might be seen as selfish or neglectful. Even if he didn't want to be a parent, once a child is born, there's a responsibility beyond just money. The child's emotional needs are important too.

So, putting it all together, even though he's not breaking any laws, the author is ethically in the wrong because he's not fulfilling his parental responsibilities beyond financial support, and he's denying the child a relationship with him. So the answer should be A.
